author: @latestly
title: Jharkhand: Tribals Gather in Support of Delisting Rally Demanding Denial of ST Reservation Benefits After Religious Conversion in Ranchi (Watch Video) | ðŸ“° LatestLY
text: Under the banner of Janjatiya Suraksha Manch, thousands of tribals gathered in support of the delisting rally through which they demanded that the converted Christians or any other religion should be denied the benefits of reservation and their names should be deleted from the ST list. The event was organized at the Morabadi Ground in Jharkhandâ€™s capital Ranchi on Sunday, December 24. [BJP MP Nishikant Dubey Says Tribals Converting to Other Religions Should Not Get Reservation Benefits.](https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/india-news-tribals-converting-to-other-religions-should-not-get-reservation-benefits-bjp-mp-nishikant-dubey-4587548.html) Tribals Gathered in Support of Delisting Rally Demanding in Ranchi [#WATCH]| Ranchi, Jharkhand: Under the banner of Janjatiya Suraksha Manch, thousands of tribals gathered at the Morabadi Ground in support of delisting rally through which they demanded that the converted Christians or any other religion should be denied the benefits ofâ€¦ [pic.twitter.com/Zli5cr17C8] â€” ANI (@ANI) [December 24, 2023] (SocialLY brings you all the latest breaking news, viral trends and information from social media world, including Twitter, Instagram and Youtube. author: Jorge Luis Pinedo Barrera
title: COVID-19: Gobierno no prohibirÃ¡ reuniones ni fiestas de AÃ±o Nuevo pese a incremento de contagios | RPP Noticias
text: El jefe del Gabinete Ministerial, [Alberto OtÃ¡rola](https://rpp.pe/noticias/alberto-otarola), afirmÃ³ en conferencia de prensa que las actividades por el recibimiento del [AÃ±o Nuevo 2024](https://rpp.pe/noticias/ano-nuevo) podrÃ¡n realizarse a pesar [del incremento de contagios de la COVID-19 en varias partes del PerÃº](https://rpp.pe/peru/actualidad/covid-19-minsa-deteca-incremento-de-casos-en-costas-sur-y-norte-ademas-del-oriente-del-pais-noticia-1524319). [Alberto OtÃ¡rola](https://rpp.pe/noticias/alberto-otarola), presidente del Consejo de Ministros, afirmÃ³ que el Gobierno no prohibirÃ¡ las reuniones ni fiestas por [AÃ±o Nuevo](https://rpp.pe/noticias/ano-nuevo), pese al incremento de contagios de la [COVID-19](https://rpp.pe/noticias/covid-19) registrados en las Ãºltimas semanas en diversas regiones del paÃ­s, ademÃ¡s [de los primeros 12 casos detectados del nuevo linaje JN.1](https://rpp.pe/peru/actualidad/ins-identifica-12-casos-del-linaje-jn1-de-la-covid-19-en-el-peru-noticia-1524343). Al respecto, el jefe del Gabinete Ministerial asegurÃ³ que â€œla enfermedad estÃ¡ controladaâ€ y exhortÃ³ a la poblaciÃ³n a completar el esquema de vacunaciÃ³n contra la COVID-19 y cumplir las medidas de prevenciÃ³n contra la transmisiÃ³n del virus. â€œNo habrÃ¡ ninguna medida restrictiva, la poblaciÃ³n tiene programada sus reuniones de fin de aÃ±o, no se suspenderÃ¡ ninguna actividad, pero sÃ­ reitero el llamado para cuidarnos y vacunarnos. La mejor medida que uno pueda tomar es ponerse la vacuna bivalente, hay suficientes en todo el PerÃºâ€, seÃ±alÃ³ OtÃ¡rola en conferencia de prensa tras realizarse una nueva sesiÃ³n del Consejo de Ministros. Hace un llamado a la calma Por otra parte, el ministro de [Salud](https://rpp.pe/noticias/ministerio-de-salud), CÃ©sar VÃ¡squez, seÃ±alÃ³ que era previsible el aumento de contagios por este virus debido al cambio de estaciÃ³n y a la aglomeraciÃ³n de personas producto de las fiestas de fin de aÃ±o. En esa lÃ­nea, el titular del Minsa precisÃ³ que hasta noviembre el promedio de casos por semanas era entre 600 y 700, mientras que en diciembre la cifra se elevÃ³ por semana a 1700. "Este aumento es mÃ¡s o menos el triple de lo normal, pero no ha significado un incremento de hospitalizaciones por esta causa. La COVID-19 trajo dolor y muerte en su momento, pero en la actualidad todos prÃ¡cticamente ya tienen defensas contra este virus, algunos por respuesta natural de su cuerpo y otros inducidos por la vacuna", afirmÃ³. "Quiero llamar a la calma a la ciudadanÃ­a, que sigan con su vida normal, pero si hay sÃ­ntomas como tos, resfrÃ­o, fiebre, pÃ©rdida del gusto, es decir, sÃ­ntomas compatibles con la COVID, hay que usar mascarilla bÃ¡sicamente para no contagiar a un adulto mayor vulnerable y sin vacunar porque para Ã©l sÃ­ podrÃ­a ser mortal", agregÃ³. title: Mujer muriÃ³ en medio de un â€œritual de sanaciÃ³nâ€ en Antioquia; su hijo contÃ³ quÃ© fue lo que pasÃ³
text: Una mujer de 53 aÃ±os muriÃ³ en las Ãºltimas horas en medio de un â€œritual de sanaciÃ³nâ€ que practicaba en el barrio Santa BÃ¡rbara, del municipio de ItagÃ¼Ã­, en el departamento de Antioquia. Los hechos se presentaron hacia las 11 de la noche del pasado miÃ©rcoles, 22 de mayo.sustancia que supuestamente le generÃ³ los problemas de salud que posteriormente acabaron con su vida. â€œRecepcionamos llamada por parte del centro asistencial que informÃ³ sobre una ciudadana, de 53 aÃ±os de edad, que ingresÃ³ sin signos vitales a la instituciÃ³n. De inmediato, nos dirigimos al lugar y nos entrevistamos con uno de sus familiares que manifestÃ³ que la seÃ±ora se encontraba, momentos antes, realizando un ritual de sanaciÃ³nâ€, explicÃ³ el mayor Henry Jaramillo, oficial de supervisiÃ³n de la PolicÃ­a de ItagÃ¼Ã­.La abuela y su compaÃ±ero sentimental fueron absueltos. Una de las asistentes fue sentenciada a cinco aÃ±os por favorecimiento. Mientras que el principal testigo recibiÃ³ 40 aÃ±os. Este Ãºltimo fue clave en el proceso de judicializaciÃ³n. En noviembre de 2023 llegÃ³ a un preacuerdo con la FiscalÃ­a a cambio de revelar los secretos del atroz ataque que conmoviÃ³ al paÃ­s en 2022: â€œEste hombre fue sentenciado por los delitos de homicidio agravado, tortura agravada y desapariciÃ³n forzada agravadaâ€.

author: Akilah Davis
title: Cary woman carries on Jewish family legacy as congregation president: 'They would be proud'
text:
CARY, N.C. (WTVD) -- JoAnne Aronson Rosenblum's Jewish roots run deep in North Carolina. She was the first woman to become president of a temple in Asheville and follows a longstanding family tradition.
"My father, grandfather and great grandfather were all involved as presidents of congregations in North Carolina," said Rosenblum. "I think they would be very, very proud."
Rosenblum can trace her roots back to the 1800s in North Carolina when her great grandfathers founded both the first and second synagogues in the state. Solomon Bear founded the Temple of Israel in Wilmington. Isaac Wallace formed Congregation Emmanuel in Statesville.
The North Carolina business established by Jewish immigrants David and Isaac Wallace in 1859 as a retail and wholesale mercantile house in Statesville was recognized on a highway historical marker last October. The brothers owned the largest herbarium in the world at the time. The dedication is located close to the Statesville Civic Center.
It is pride Rosenblum has shown every day since she was 16 years old by wearing the Star of David around her neck. At 74, that pride still shines.
"I was brought up in a very small town of Statesville. There were very few Jews at the time I was growing up. There was antisemitism, but it was instilled that being Jewish is a special thing," she said.
It is so special that it's something Leonard Rogoff spent years researching.
"No one had really done comprehensive research on the history of Jews in North Carolina," he said.
The historian turned author wrote a book called "Down Home Jewish Life in North Carolina" that documents families who have lived in the state for hundreds of years.
"They felt unrecognized and disconnected from this newer community that has emerged. People are unaware of this history," said Rogoff.
He told ABC11 that the Jewish community has grown over the last 30 years in North Carolina. He's now hoping his work lives on and can bridge the gap between generations.
"This was a way of bringing the Jewish community back together again," he said.

author: Daniel Green, Noozhawk Staff Writer
title: Community Steps Up to Raise Funds for Owner of Collapsed Home in Santa Barbara
text:
Months after a landslide took out part of Las Alturas Road and sent a home sliding down a hillside above Santa Barbara, residents are still trying to help the former occupants.
The Riviera home, which belongs to Jan Luc, was condemned by the
City of Santa Barbara in April.
In the aftermath, neighbor Jan Campbell set up a
GoFundMe fundraiser to help Luc and her family relocate and pay for cost-of-living needs.
Luc lived there with her two sons, Ben and Patrick.
â€œWhen I saw what happened to her house, I was shocked,â€ Campbell said.
Campbell, who has known the family for years, first worked alongside Luc at the accounting firm
Bartlett, Pringle & Wolf. Luc would later babysit Campbellâ€™s two daughters.
Campbell also noted that Lucâ€™s late husband built the home in the 1970s.
In the immediate aftermath of the landslide, Campbell struggled to find Luc or learn what happened to her, but later found out she was living in a hotel in Goleta.
â€œI was shocked at how upbeat and positive she was,â€ Campbell said. â€œI mean for something like that to happen when youâ€™re in your late 80s is pretty devastating, but she always had a really good sense of humor.â€
Campbell decided to set up a GoFundMe account to help with the cost of the damage.
Campbell had a similar experience during the Tea Fire in 2008, when her home was damaged by the flames. The Tea Fire caused
one death and dozens of injuries, along with destroying more than 200 homes.
Currently, the GoFundMe for Lucâ€™s family has raised a little more than $19,600 of its $25,000 goal and is still open.
City Monitoring Road Conditions
City officials say they are monitoring the home and the section of Las Alturas Road that collapsed, but the area is currently stable.
According to Tina Dye, the chief building official for the city, the cost of removing the condemned home will be borne by the homeowner since the land is considered private property.
Besides being tagged as uninhabitable, Dye said, the home has no code violations.
The section of Las Alturas Road near the house is still sectioned off with sandbags and tape. The road is also being limited to a single lane road for the foreseeable future.
According to principal engineer Laura Yanez, the city is confident in the status of the road.
â€œCurrently, the road is stable,â€ Yanez said. â€œWeâ€™re not seeing any further damage on one lane of traffic.â€
Yanez also confirmed that the city is working with a geotechnical firm to determine what the next steps are for restoring the road.
The firm,
Cotton, Shires and Associates, is expected to do an assessment of the area in July, and come back with an update in the month after that.
After receiving the report, the city will move forward regarding the road and any repairs.
Yanez also said the city is aware of concerns about possible damage to water pipes and sewage lines raised by neighbors.
â€œWeâ€™re actively monitoring the area and have no reasons to be concerned,â€ Yanez said.
Campbell said the support for Luc from the community has been overwhelming, and has restored her faith in humanity.
â€œSanta Barbara is a very generous community,â€ Campbell said. â€œI think it was people who wanted to help, and I mean anywhere from a little bit to a lot. They just wanted to be part of a group of people that helped someone else.â€
Click here to donate to the GoFundMe account.

Nvidia's AI avatar sat on my computer screen and weirded me out
Published by
Techcrunch
on Fri, 10 Jan 2025
Nvidia unveiled a prototype AI avatar at CES 2025 that lives on your PCs desktop. The AI assistant, R2X, looks like a video game character, and it can help you navigate apps on your computer. The R2X avatar is rendered and animated using Nvidias AI models, and users can run the avatar on popular LLMs [] 2024 TechCrunch. All rights reserved. For personal use only.
